Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Situation2: The ambulance is transporting a critically ill patient through a severe thunderstorm with slick roads and low visibility.
Story: I had promised Mia we’d finally have a quiet evening together this week—just the two of us, no interruptions. We’d both cleared our schedules, and she’d been looking forward to it, texting me ideas for dinner and movies. But now, as I gripped the steering wheel of the ambulance, rain hammered the windshield, and lightning split the sky. The patient in the back was barely hanging on, and every second counted. Dispatch was urging me to hurry, but the roads were slick, visibility almost nothing. My mind kept flickering back to Mia, to her hopeful smile, to the promise I’d made. But here, in this storm, someone’s life depended on me not just being fast, but careful. I felt torn in two—one part of me desperate to keep my word to Mia, to be the boyfriend she deserved, the other part knowing that right now, I was the only thing standing between a stranger and disaster. My hands tightened on the wheel, heart pounding, as I tried to figure out how to be both things at once.
